items.title: global default for startsecs
items.body:
The [`startsecs`](http://supervisord.org/configuration.html#program-x-section-example)  configuration value controls how long a program has to stay alive to transition into the `RUNNING` state. This can currently only configured inside the `[program:]` section and there is no global default, except for the hardcoded one 1s.

Are you interested in promoting this to a `[supervisord] startsecs=` configuration, which acts as a fall back for `[program:] startsecs=` and defaults to 1?

items.title: Termination of supervisor after (regular or abnormal) termination of process
items.body:
Hi, 

YES, I am fully aware of issue #712 and that all issues around the problem of terminating supervisord after one of it's subprocesses terminated is a frequently asked question which always will be ignored by triaging as a duplicate of #712. 

However: #712 is not a solution. It's an ugly and cumbersome workaround to have a separate python process just to tell to stop. 

Since supervisord is more and more often used in docker images, which expect to have a single responsible task to terminate after beeing finished or having a problem, and it should be easy to implement, it should be possible to have a configuration option for programs that simply tells supervisor to terminate (with all living children) after a process has terminated 
- in any case
- in an abnormal way where it wouldn't be restarted or
- after the given number of restarting tries has failed. 

Having a separate process just to tell supervisor 'it's over now' is not a clean style and just a workaround for the moment. Since #712 is more than four years old, there should have been a clean solution meanwhile. And after all, terminating supervisord and it's children (as if it had received a ctrl-c/signal) should already exist as a function, it just needs to be called if the function is set. 

regards

items.title: Supervisord blocks aioredis in combination with Quart
items.body:
I am using the [Quart](https://pgjones.gitlab.io/quart/) web server framework together with aioredis.

aioredis is listening for Redis events and executing certain actions then. For testing purposes, I just issue these Redis PUB/SUB events from the `redis-cli` command line interface.

Now the problem is: if I run my server like `python main.py` everything works well and new events trigger the actions immediately.

However, if I run my `python main.py` command through my supervisord configuration, the event listener is blocking as long as no web server request is being made. This means, if I load a page like `localhost:5000/` then, I will get all previously blocked Redis event messages bundled and at once.

I'm really confused by this behavior. The Quart dev doesn't have an exact idea either. Maybe the problem could have something to do with forking or permissions? (Note: I already tried running my supervisord server with `nodeaemon=true` which didn't help.)

Here's some code:

```python
async def observe_redis_events(channel, action):
    try:
        app.logger.debug(f"Starting redis client to observe '{channel}' events")
        own_redis_db = await aioredis.create_redis((config.redis_host, config.redis_port), db=config.redis_db, encoding="utf-8") # private redis client to observe just the specific events
        target_channels = await own_redis_db.subscribe(channel)
    except Exception as e:
        app.logger.exception("Could not subscribe to redis event channel.")
    app.logger.debug(f"Redis event subscription to channel '{channel}' established.")
    observed_channel = target_channels[0]

    print(f"Waiting on {channel}")
    try:
        while await observed_channel.wait_message():      # <- this will wait for a new message and is blocking to long when used with supervisord (because it somehow waits for a web request to the Quart server!)
            print("Parsing")
            message = await observed_channel.get_json()
            print("Executing Action.")
            await action(**message)
            print("Finished.")
    except Exception as e:
        app.logger.exception("Not so good.")
    
    app.loger.debug(f"Redis event subscription to channel '{channel}' ended.")

@app.before_serving
async def startup():
    asyncio.get_running_loop().create_task(observe_redis_events("game", notify_game_update))
```

The redis-cli command:
`PUBLISH game "{\"info\": \"Hello World!\"}"`
but this can be really just anything.

And here are the relevant parts from my supervisord.conf:

```
[supervisord]
logfile=logs/supervisord.log
logfile_maxbytes=20MB

[unix_http_server]
file=/tmp/supervisor.sock
username=[...]
password=[...]

[rpcinterface:supervisor]
supervisor.rpcinterface_factory=supervisor.rpcinterface:make_main_rpcinterface

[supervisorctl]
serverurl=unix:///tmp/supervisor.sock
username=[...]
password=[...]
prompt=[...]

[program:server]
command=python main.py
stdout_logfile=logs/%(program_name)s.log
redirect_stderr=true

[group:full_environment]
programs=[...],[...],server
```

P.S.: I run all this in a Python 3.7 venv. My supervisord is installed there and only for that single project. I also stopped all other services to see if it's really the main server which makes the problems or if it's another program which causes the problems on the main server - but it's really just the `main.py` which has problems in combination with supervisord.

Do you have any idea what might be causing those weird problems.

Best regards!

items.title: Add prefix to supervisord program stdout logs
items.body:
I'm using supervisord in Docker and have my application logs configured like so:

```
redirect_stderr=true
stdout_logfile=/dev/stdout
stdout_logfile_maxbytes=0
```

In the stdout of supervisord, though, the messages get displayed directly from the subprocesses, and it is not always possible to tell which subprocess is responsible for which log message.  For example, I see something like this:

```
2020-02-08 20:49:27,572 INFO supervisord started with pid 1
2020-02-08 20:49:28,583 INFO spawned: 'nginx' with pid 8
2020-02-08 20:49:28,585 INFO spawned: 'php-fpm' with pid 9
[08-Feb-2020 20:49:28] NOTICE: fpm is running, pid 9
[08-Feb-2020 20:49:28] NOTICE: ready to handle connections
[08-Feb-2020 20:49:28] NOTICE: systemd monitor interval set to 10000ms
```

The first 3 messages are from supervisord itself, and the last 3 are from php-fpm.  I would rather see something like this:

```
2020-02-08 20:49:27,572 INFO supervisord started with pid 1
2020-02-08 20:49:28,583 INFO spawned: 'nginx' with pid 8
2020-02-08 20:49:28,585 INFO spawned: 'php-fpm' with pid 9
2020-02-08 20:49:28,600 INFO program php-fpm: NOTICE: fpm is running, pid 9
2020-02-08 20:49:28,601 INFO program php-fpm: NOTICE: ready to handle connections
2020-02-08 20:49:28,602 INFO program php-fpm: NOTICE: systemd monitor interval set to 10000ms
```

Then, if I'm interested only in the logs from php-fpm, I can easily grep for them.

items.title: Uvicorn webscoket redirected as stderr
items.body:
**Context**
 Using Django with channels behind Nginx as reverse proxy. Everything work to establish communication and response but the supervisor logging catch the Uvicorn log for WebSocket as error and write it in the error file...

**Configuration**

- supervisor.ini
```
[supervisord]

[fcgi-program:uvicorn]
socket = unix:///tmp/my-unix.sock

command = /home/user/.virtualenvs/my-env/bin/uvicorn --fd 0 app.asgi:application
numprocs = 1
process_name = %(program_name)s_%(process_num)02d

stdout_logfile = /home/user/stdout.log
stdout_logfile_maxbytes = 1MB
stdout_logfile_backups = 10
stdout_events_enabled = false

stderr_logfile = /home/user/stderr.log
stderr_logfile_maxbytes = 1MB
stderr_logfile_backups = 10
stderr_events_enabled = false
```

**Log files**

- stdout.log
```
INFO:      - "GET /home/ HTTP/1.0" 200 OK
INFO:      - "GET /my-page/ HTTP/1.0" 200 OK
```

- stderr.log

```
INFO:     Started server process [666]
INFO:     Waiting for application startup.
INFO:     ASGI 'lifespan' protocol appears unsupported.
INFO:     Application startup complete.
INFO:     Uvicorn running on socket /tmp/my-unix.sock (Press CTRL+C to quit)
INFO:     None - "WebSocket /ws/" [accepted]
```

**Problem** 
The line `INFO:     None - "WebSocket /ws/" [accepted]` in **stderr.log** should be redirected in **stdout.log** because the connection is correctly established (and work as well). Maybe just a little problem to handle the request as *success* for *supervisor*  because it's WebSocket request? Not status code and `None` make him think it's error???

items.title: reread does not respect changes to running services
items.body:
A service is running with autorestart=true which would mean that if it crashed or exited on its own, supervisord would restart it. Great.

Then I rewrite the service definition and set autorestart=false and issue a "reread" and supervisord correctly reports that that service has changed.

But now if the service's process crashes or exits, I would want supervisord to respect the new service definition and NOT restart the process but it does restart it.

In general, I want supervisord to apply the output of the reread to the existing process groups.

We are coming from using systemd where "systemctl daemon-reload" behaves this way and it makes sense.

Is this behavior by design or an issue we can address?

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/py2_warn.py:19: UserWarning: ************************************************************

items.title: Suggestion: Setting to load environment from file, for safe secret handling
items.body:
Currently, the handling of application secrets under `supervisord` is inflexible and potentially unsafe. If passed as environment variables (a standard practice), the secrets must live in the supervisord configuration file itself, which is not particularly secure (it might need to be checked into source control, e.g.; or be readable to non-root users).

It would be useful if there were a setting parallel to the `environment` key which could take environments from the filesystem, e.g. `environment_file=/path/to/resource`, where the target file contains `KEY=value` pairs, one per line.

This way, the environment file can be owned by `root`, and have `-r--------` permissions; then `supervisord` could read the file and build its environment as root *before* reducing permissions for the daemonized application. This way, the secrets don't have to be saved in configurations (thus inheriting their permissions), or be readable to the child process, or possibly be checked into source repos.

There is precedent for this in (for example) `uwsgi`, which has the `--envdir` option, which essentially functions as above; except keys are filenames in the provided directory, and the values are the file contents— this could be another way to expose this functionality which might be more friendly to multi-line variable values.

items.title: Support for nested groups?
items.body:
It seems that a `[group:x]` can only launch programs, could it be upgraded to control nested groups? This would be really handy to be able to collect related groups into a larger group, i.e.

```
[group:sensors]
programs=lidar,gps

[group:algorithms]
programs=sensor_fusion,mapping

[group:main]
groups=sensors,algorithms
```

Right now, main would have to list all 4 programs, since groups cannot be listed. What sort of effort might be involved in adding a feature like this? We could be open to paying for the work.

items.title: Support conditional statements for autostart/autorestart values
items.body:
Is it currently possible, and if not, would it be possible to implement a way to support conditional statements which would return a boolean which would then be used as value of autostart and autorestart in supervisor.conf file ?

Example:
```
[program:some_script]
command=sh -c 'sleep 15 && php /var/www/public/myScript.php'
autostart=%(APPLICATION_ENV)s == 'staging'
autorestart=%(APPLICATION_DB)s == 'test'
```

Currently we can just use this:
`autostart=%(APPLICATION_ENV_IS_STAGING)s` 
But then this specific environment variable must be explicitly defined as a boolean value prior to running supervisord, and we don't need it any anywhere else than supervisor configs.

items.title: Syslog support in python3 is broken
items.body:
## Problem

When running `supervisord` under python3 with a configuration that includes the program option `stdout_syslog = true`, messages do not show up in syslog.


## Versions tested

- 4.0.4
- ff7f18169bcc8091055f61279d0a63997d594148 (latest master at the time)


## Debugging

When running `supervisord` with `--nodaemon`, exception tracebacks reveal the problem:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/staley/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/supervisor/loggers.py", line 372, in emit
    for line in message.rstrip('\n').split('\n'):
TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'
```

`SyslogHandler.emit` is being passed a record that contains a message objects of type `bytes` not `str`. Passing `str` objects into the `rstrip` and `split` methods of a `byte` object is not allowed.

items.title: allow supervisor to be behind a reverse proxy sub url (add base_url param)
items.body:
Hi,

In some cases I'd like to put supervisor behind one (or a chain of reverse proxies and be able to access it via a sub url)

Example:
I'd like the supervisor web interface to be acessible via
https://myserver.mydomain.com/supervisor/

Under some circumstances (using haproxy as a tcp proxy with sni detection, forwarding to nginx ssl terminal with the haproxy proxy protocol and then pointing to the http_inetserver redirects / links within the supervisor web interface are wrong (bad port number or bad url without the desired /supervisor/ prefix.

havin ab optional  base_url parameter in the [inet_http_server] could solve this issue.

In my example the parameter would be set to
base_url = https://myserver.mydomain.com/supervisor/

and the whole web interface would prefix it's links with the base url.

Alternatively. 
Perhaps there are already tricks to configure a haproxy / nginx setup such, that this feature is not necessary.

In this case a documentation of how to configure nginx could be helpful:

On some servers following nginx setup seems to do the trick:

```
   location ^~ /supervisor/ {
        rewrite ^/supervisor(/.*) $1 break;
        proxy_pass http://localhost:9001/;
        proxy_set_header Host $host/supervisor/;  # I'm not even sure this is really legal but it seems to do
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";
   }
```

But on more complex setups I'd really need some advice of how to achieve this and I think the base_url param would be a simple way. (such an approach is done by quite some web apps)

Example which I did not get to work:

Desired url, that should allow me to connect to supervisor
https://myserver.mydomain.com/supervisor/

this will arrive at an haproxy in tcp mode, which will redirect to an nginx via
https://internalhostname:444/supervisor (with the haproxy protocol)
and this one would have an nginx configuration like the above example:

However the generated urls do contain the port 444 and will be translated to
https://myserver.mydomain.com:444/supervisor/

Thus the setup is broken.

items.title: Reread/restart/update is still confusing
items.body:
It is somewhat a continuation of #720 that is closed but contains comments from a lot of confused people.

### My problem

I need to restart service X exactly once after its package is updated. It contains service binary and a part of supervisord configuration that is `include`-ed from the main file.

### My attempts

1. `supervisorctl update` does not restart service if configuration file did not change, old binary is still running.
2. `supervisorctl restart` restarts service with the old configuration, the new configuration is not used.
3. `supervisorctl reread && supervisorctl restart` does the same as the one above – and that is very surprising!
4. `supervisorctl update && supervisorctl restart` restarts service twice if configuration file changed.

### My solution

```sh
supervisorctl reread

supervisorctl stop X
supervisorctl remove X
supervisorctl add X  # that also starts X as I have `autostart = true` in configuration
```

That works. But is it really the best way? 
And why attempt 3 did not work?

items.title: restart program with current (possibly updated) system environment variable
items.body:
For now, if a system environment variable is updated after supervisord was started, when we restarting a program (i.e, a subprocess)，the program won't read the updated environment variable.

Here's my reproducing procedure:
```bash
$ supervisord --version
4.0.4

$ cat supervisord.conf
[supervisord]
loglevel = debug

[rpcinterface:supervisor]
supervisor.rpcinterface_factory = supervisor.rpcinterface:make_main_rpcinterface

[unix_http_server]
file=supervisor.sock

[supervisorctl]
serverurl=unix://supervisor.sock

[program:foo]
command = /usr/bin/env
startsecs = 0
autorestart = false

$ export FOO=bar

$ supervisord -c supervisord.conf

$ cat supervisord.log
2019-08-03 15:03:05,438 INFO RPC interface 'supervisor' initialized
2019-08-03 15:03:05,438 CRIT Server 'unix_http_server' running without any HTTP authentication checking
2019-08-03 15:03:05,438 INFO daemonizing the supervisord process
2019-08-03 15:03:05,439 INFO supervisord started with pid 10963
2019-08-03 15:03:06,443 INFO spawned: 'foo' with pid 10968
2019-08-03 15:03:06,449 DEBG 'foo' stdout output:
... a bunch of environment variables ...
FOO=bar

2019-08-03 15:03:06,449 DEBG fd 9 closed, stopped monitoring <POutputDispatcher at 140011491691936 for <Subprocess at 140011492025064 with name foo in state STARTING> (stderr)>
2019-08-03 15:03:06,449 INFO success: foo entered RUNNING state, process has stayed up for > than 0 seconds (startsecs)
2019-08-03 15:03:06,449 DEBG fd 7 closed, stopped monitoring <POutputDispatcher at 140011491691768 for <Subprocess at 140011492025064 with name foo in state RUNNING> (stdout)>
2019-08-03 15:03:06,449 INFO exited: foo (exit status 0; expected)
2019-08-03 15:03:06,449 DEBG received SIGCHLD indicating a child quit
```

after a while, if I change the environment variable FOO to a new value "baz", and restart program:foo, the foo program won't get the new value. Instead, the FOO environment variable remain what it was when supervisord was started (i.e, "bar", same as before):
```bash
$ export FOO=baz

$ supervisorctl -c supervisord.conf restart foo

$ less supervisord.log
...log last time...

2019-08-03 15:03:53,225 INFO spawned: 'foo' with pid 11006
2019-08-03 15:03:53,226 INFO success: foo entered RUNNING state, process has stayed up for > than 0 seconds (startsecs)
2019-08-03 15:03:53,228 DEBG 'foo' stdout output:
... same here, a bunch of environment variables, FOO's value doesn't change ...
FOO=bar

2019-08-03 15:03:53,228 DEBG fd 10 closed, stopped monitoring <POutputDispatcher at 140011491321504 for <Subprocess at 140011492025064 with name foo in state RUNNING> (stderr)>
2019-08-03 15:03:53,228 DEBG fd 8 closed, stopped monitoring <POutputDispatcher at 140011491691768 for <Subprocess at 140011492025064 with name foo in state RUNNING> (stdout)>
2019-08-03 15:03:53,229 INFO exited: foo (exit status 0; expected)
2019-08-03 15:03:53,229 DEBG received SIGCHLD indicating a child quit
```

To my understanding, program:foo inherits its environment variables from supervisord daemon process. So here I restart program:foo without restarting supervisord. The new environment variable won't take effect.

Maybe we need some kind of mechanism for supervisord the reread the system environment before starting the programs it supervise. Like some way to reload os.environ

I wonder if this issue should be addresses by supervisor, or by user. If user should deal with this situation, is restarting supervisord with all the programs it supervise the only way? or there is more elegant way to do it.

items.title: Stop commands in parallel with supervisorctl instead of sequentially
items.body:
When performing `supervisorctl stop all`, the commands seems to get stopped in parallel, i.e. all at the same time. In my case stopping all ~30 child processes takes 20 seconds to execute. The feedback supervisorctl gives me when I issue the command is that it waits for all processes to stop at the same time and then show all processes stopped at once.

When I issue `supervisorctl stop command1:* command2:* command3:* command4:* command5:* ` it takes a whopping 85 seconds to execute, and the feedback I get is that it waits for each command to stop before stopping the next one (stopping them sequentially).

Is it possible have the commands stopped the same way (in parallel) as `stop all` when passing them as argument to supervisorctl ? Is there a workaround for this ?

items.title: supervisord parsing new lines in logs
items.body:
We have an application that is outputting logs with `\n` characters in them. When supervisord gets these logs and displays the output, it's evaluating the `\n`s and causing multiple lines of output to occur when we originally wanted only one. Since we're feeding our logs into DataDog, it's causing our logs to get polluted with a bunch of individual lines when it shouldn't be. 

**Example output:**
Correct: 
```
[Fri May 17 19:46:23.629839 2019] [php7:notice] [pid 90] [client 10.234.206.61:12348] [2019-05-17 15:46:23] production.NOTICE: array (\n  'message' => 'preparing to decode json payload',\n  'memory_usage' => '4 MB',\n  'size' => '0.31 MB',\n)  \n, referer: https://dev.site.com/
```

supervisord output:
```
[2019-05-17 16:00:05] production.NOTICE: array (
  'message' => 'preparing to decode json payload',
  'memory_usage' => '18 MB',
  'size' => '0 MB',
)
```

How can we get it to stop evaluating the `\n`'s like that?

items.title: Remove /tmp/supervisor.sock from sample.conf
items.body:
The `supervisor/skel/sample.conf` has two lines that refer to `/tmp/supervisor.sock`:

```
file=/tmp/supervisor.sock   ; the path to the socket file
```

and

```
serverurl=unix:///tmp/supervisor.sock ; use a unix:// URL  for a unix socket
```

This is a dangerous place for a file; I find my new linux distros (in Amazon) are removing this file after some period of time.  https://github.com/Supervisor/supervisor/issues/1105

Please change this to `/etc/supervisor.sock`, or some other safer place.

items.title: feature suggestion: turn off log rotation by default
items.body:
To me the primary features that supervisor provides really have nothing to do with log rotation. It seems like a feature that was added to avoid people filling up disks because they don't realize logs need rotation. 

I recently found out that rotation happens when supervisor started beating logrotate to the punch and then not creating the new files with the proper user. Logrotate was configured to do daily rotations and supervisor was configured (by default and with no way of knowing it was doing it) at 50megs. 

My suggestion would be to have rotation turned off by default. 

The docs are also rather ambiguous about what exactly gets rotated. After reading them, I assumed supervisor would only rotate its own log, not any subprocess logs.

[http://supervisord.org/logging.html#activity-log-rotation](url)

If you read that without knowing a priori that the child logs are rotated, you would assume they aren't by default.

I'm happy to take a crack at updating the docs via a PR if that would help, maybe it would save someone some time.

A few other thought came up from all this:

is there a way to find out what supervisord is using as its setttings. I was specifying a specific config file, but something like 

> supervisord --echo_settings

 would have led me to the issue right away. 

And then my final thought would be to drop the multiple locations of finding config files and just make the user specify which one they want to use. I found a lot of issues online where people were having supervisor use config files that they weren't expecting. 

Thanks for the app. Let me know about the PR for the docs.

items.body:
I'm stuck with a distro-provided version of supervisord at version 2.something, and I'm running into lots of frustrating problems which are probably due to my trying to use 3.x options that aren't supported but don't generate errors, they're just silently ignored.

The documentation for 2.x and 3.x versions of supervisord seems to have disappeared from the Internet. Usually, there's a drop-down for readthedocs.io-hosted documentation which lets you switch which release you're looking at.

Is it possible the project maintainers could switch that on? Or has the build process for the documentation simply diverged too much since the 2.x and 3.x days?

Anyway, something seems wrong about expecting people to use the Wayback Machine for this.

items.title: serialize concurrent supervisord commands that change state (start, stop, restart)
items.body:
Suppose that several restart commands are issued in parallel via supervisorctl as illustrated below
`# supervisorctl -c /path/to/supervisord.conf restart all & supervisorctl -c /path/to/supervisord.conf restart all & supervisorctl -c /path/to/supervisord.conf restart all &`

Currently (latest versions) these commands may result in a mess, some old process hierarchies mixed with new ones, some processes will be down, other random ones will be up, no consistency, dependencies may not be satisfied.

Proposed behaviour - supervisord receives change requests such as stop, start, restart and executes them serially, only after the previous command has fully completed, whereas read only commands like status may be satisfied immediately.

The scenario described here (concurrent change requests) is not really contrived. For instance, you may have daemon1 and daemon2 which may issue restarts without coordination with one another.
